Notes: Contract Start
Added functionality
Program terminated after it was determined that it would cost $2.2 billion in development to get maybe 25% functionality; about $750 million in lost projected benefits to date
Contract Start

North Carolina spent at least $36 million (net)  to keep legacy system going because of the delay; Medicaid certification expected summer 2014, didn't happen until March 2015 becasuse of extensive bugs in system.
Procurement Begins
Development begins in earnest
Launched "ahead" of Schedule

Original set out as two system developments, the Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade
(CCNPAU) and Continued Claims Redesign (CCR),  which were then merged into one.
Projects merged into one, yet with separate still with completion dates
More changes to producrement - notice shortening of CCNPAU schedule
More changes to producrement - notice shortening of CCR schedule
CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, but complaints about call wait times have been rampant
CCR was rolled out over Labor Day weekend - was a total disaster (see Risk Factor Blog).
Contract to IBM was for $6.19 million for new payroll system
Goes live with disasterous effects,  IBM cost now is $25.7 million (still owed $3 million ); many staff underpaid, while $112.m million was overpaid as of May 2012
Govt decides to spend another $209 million to try to fix system
Govt claims system is stabilized

Another $220.5 million needed to fix, and $837 million to operate for next 5 years; $91 m in overpayments still owed (note, a KPMG report says the development cost is closer to $515 million with another $25 million needed to see what other fixes are needed;

FiReControl was to replacing 46 local control rooms with a network of nine purpose-built regional control centers using a national computer system to handle calls, mobilise equipment and manage incidents. Initial rollout was due in October 2007, and final by October 2009
Increase project cost, keep schedule
Increase project cost, shorten schedule
Same project cost, increase schedule
Increase project cost, shorten schedule

Project terminated in December 2010 after spending £250 million and not impending anything of value; another £219 million in already committed costs, so a total waste of £460 million; another £180 million could be spent, the May 2015 date was a best guess, since the program was still estimated to be at least 5 years from completion
